channel.title: ASF JIRA
channel.description: This file is an XML representation of an issue

item.title: [DERBY-3653] Convert datetime.sql to JUnit
item.description: Converting the existing SQL test to JUnit, using the SQLToJunit tool.

status.description: The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are closed can be reopened.

comments.comment:
Hi, Tiaqo. I have a question, With SQLToJUnit, we will get a test class based on canon files, why not translate the SQL test into junit based on assertion?

Regards
Junjie

Hi Junjie,

With SQLToJunit the program evaluates the canon files and makes a junit test using assertions. For this test you would want to run SQLToJUnit against the datetime.tmp file created when you run the test, rather than the datetime.out file in the master directory as the .out file has filtered timestamps. The SQLToJUnit program can save you a lot of time converting a sql test to JUnit but usually there is some manual work that needs to be done after running it, such as breaking up the test into multiple fixtures.

Hi, Kathey. Thanks to your charification, I have understood how to use SQLToJUnit at last. But, I have a quesiton, how to get datetime.tmp file? What tool can be used?

Thank you!

Junjie, if you run the datetime.sql test with old test harness using the keepfiles flag, then after the test has finished executing, you will still be able to find the datetime.tmp in the directory where the test was run.
java -Dkeepfiles=true org.apache.derbyTesting.functionTests.RunTest lang/datetime.sql

I have finished the translation. But a test can not pass in CS model, while it's OK in embeded mode. The excepiton trace stack is:

java junit.textui.TestRunner org.apache.derbyTesting.f
unctionTests.tests.lang.DateTimeTest

FAILURES!!!
Tests run: 60, Failures: 1, Errors: 0

It seems, it's relevant to the time format in different modes.
Please give me a hand! Thank you!

I committed Junjie's patch with revision 689237 with one change:
I let the test accept, with comment, the difference Junjie found in behavior between Embedded and DerbyNetClient (see DERBY-3856).

I ran the old datetime.sql test with DerbyNetClient and it too showed the behavior difference - the test was just not run with DerbyNetClient before so the difference was not noticed.

The rest of the test looked fine to me and suite.All passed.
